In natural biofilms, bacteria transfer electrons to metals and even between neighboring bacteria.
The nanowire extensions of periplasm help bacteria connect with each other in a biofilm, and transfer a current to the metal electron acceptor.
The cytochromes help the bacterium donate electrons to different kinds of metals, even insoluble forms such as iron and cobalt embedded within clay.
The bacterium, named Shewanella number of different cytochromes.
Nealson’s colleague Mohamed El-Naggar found that Shewanella bacteria transfer electrons via nanowires (see Fig. 14.2).
But Nealson, like the famous nineteenth-century microbial ecologist Sergei Winogradsky, was fascinated by the metal transformations he observed in wetlands and lake sediments.
The electrons then pass within a current to the cathode.
He reasoned that only microbial activity could account for so much reduced manganese, compared to other lakes where manganese is in the oxidized form (Mn4+, as the insoluble mineral MnO2).
Up to 20 years ago, it was thought that bacteria could reduce only soluble ions such as nitrate.
What if we could harness bacterial electron transfer to power our own electrical The concept of bacterial electric power is surprisingly recent.
In 1988, Nealson and his colleague Charles Myers discovered a bacterium that could respire anaerobically by donating electrons to MnO2, releasing soluble Mn2+.
Nealson was particularly intrigued by the high levels of reduced manganese (Mn2+) found in Lake Oneida, New York.
Microbial reduction of minerals plays a critical role in every ecosystem and participates in the geochemical cycling of elements throughout Earth’s biosphere (discussed in Chapter 22).
nitrate is used up, other species reduce manganese (Mn4+ → the bottom of the lake or sediment, methanogenic archaea reduce carbon dioxide to methane (see Section 14.5).
How can bacteria reduce a substance outside their cell envelopes?
